rooms.description: A pair of wooden gates stand open here, richly carved and ornamented with fantastic beasts and stylized people in robes, with a short walkway leading to them. Beyond the gates, a roofless wooden theatre rises up, with walls around it. Excited-sounding male and female voices speaking in a foreign language waft through those walls to the outside. Beyond the theatre, rice fields spread out, with the occasional hut visible among the furrows. A road can be seen to the north.

North.description: Kitayama Row ends here.

South.description: The path ends at some kind of admission gate.

rooms.name: Rice Fields
rooms.description: Right past the beautiful Yomeimon Gate, the fields begin.  You slide a little as you enter this corner of the field.  The sheer life here overwhelms you.  You can go west, back to the road, or go on with the fields to the north or east.

North.description: The fields go as far north as your eye can see.

East.description: The fields go a ways to the east.

South.description: The wall is made of clean, grey-white stone. It rises far above your head. You can see people patrolling it.

West.description: Sumisara Way begins to to the west.

rooms.name: Rice Fields
rooms.description: The delicate rice plants sway in the gentle breeze.  You are almost relieved at the breeze, since it's the only thing alleviating the thick humidity here. You can see a thatched hut of some sort to the east, or you can head north or west to the fields.  The city wall bounds you to the south.

North.description: The rice fields stretch far to the north. You see a hut of some kind up ahead.

East.description: You see a building to the east.

West.description: You see the southwest corner of the field. Beyond that, you see a road.

rooms.name: The Workmen's Storehouse
rooms.description: You stumble out of the tall grasses to emerge into a glade of some sort.  A rickety building stands before you.  It has no door and the windows are not glassed or papered over.  You can clearly see inside it, to see the various tools of the farmer's trade: hoes, picks, hand-ploughs.

North.description: The fields go far to the north.

West.description: The fields go a ways to the west.

rooms.name: Rice Fields
rooms.description: You skirt Sumisara Way, avoiding stares from the nearby road travelers at the expense of your cleanliness.  Now you can understand why the farmers seem so ragged.  The mud and muck threaten your sanity.  However, if you still want more, you can still go north, south, or east back to the fields.

North.description: The fields go as far to the north as your eyes can see.

East.description: The fields go a short ways to the east, broken by the mountain's side.

South.description: The fields end here, bordered by a stone wall.

West.description: You see a road to the west. Beyond that, you see lush green fields.

rooms.name: Rice Fields
rooms.description: The sun beats overhead and you look around the field, suddenly hungry at the sight of all this potential food.  Speaking of which, there seems to be a threshing house to your north.

North.description: You see a well-built hut to the north.

East.description: The fields end here.

South.description: The fields end here, at the city walls.

West.description: You see more fields, and a well-kept road.

rooms.name: Rice Fields
rooms.description: The rice fields end here, bounded as they are by the sheer, unforgiving mountain that girds this entire island.  You look up, but can't see the top of the mountain from here.  You can head south to the storehouse or west or north to the fields.

North.description: The fields go a short distance to the north.

South.description: A storehouse stands to the south.

West.description: The fields go a short distance to the west.

rooms.name: Rice Fields
rooms.description: Even the swallows overhead seem to know that this is a land of life: they're making a killing on the bugs that plague you.  You fight your way through the mud and push at the grasses to get a path cleared.

North.description: The fields go far to the north.

East.description: The fields go a short distance to the east.

South.description: The fields go a short distance to the south. Beyond them, you can see the city wall.

West.description: A road runs west of here.

rooms.name: The Threshing House
rooms.description: The hut has no door and no windows.  In fact, it seems just to be a place to store bales of rice-grass before the rice grains are separated out from the grass itself.  You see curious implements all around, such as a forked stick, that seem to be designed to winnow the rice from the stalks.

North.description: The rice fields go far to the north.

East.description: The rice fields end here.

South.description: The fields go a short ways to the south. Beyond them, you can see the city walls.

West.description: The fields go a short ways. Beyond them, you can see a road, and more fields.

rooms.name: Rice Fields
rooms.description: You stand in the middle of the rice fields, in case you hadn't noticed from the tall green stalks and shoots that sway all around you.  With every step you are probably destroying a family's entire meal, you monster.  You can see a hedge to your east that obscures whatever is beyond it.

North.description: The fields go a short ways to the north.

South.description: The fields extend to the south, ending at the city walls far away.

West.description: You see a hut to the south.

rooms.name: The Anteroom
rooms.description: A plain, unfurnished room.  Your feet trod delicate tatami mats made of woven reeds.  The sunlight pours in from a skylight above.  You can tell that if you chose to meditate here that you would find peace.  You can only go east back to the tea room proper.

East.description: You see a small, sparsely furnished room with a firepit in it.

rooms.name: The Tea Room
rooms.description: You enter the room almost hushed in reverence.  The quiet inside is broken periodically by the cries of swallows outside.  A great tea master once said that "Empty space is imperishable.  " And it shows here.  A fire-pit is in the middle of the room, surrounded by thin cushions.  The sunlight spills into the room from the skylights above.  A rack hangs on one wall.  You can go into the anteroom from here, or north back to the alcove, or east to the porch to think and to look outside.

North.description: You see a quiet alcove.

East.description: To the east, you see a porch overlooking a pretty cherry tree orchard.

West.description: You see an unfurnished anteroom.

extras.text: Against the wall you see an iron rack line with all kinds of instruments whose function you can only guess at - short whisks and brushes, ornately carved sticks, and more.

rooms.name: The Outer Porch
rooms.description: You step past the open shoji, admiring their carvings of chrysanthemums and herons.  On the porch, you rest your elbows on a low openwork fence around the porch itself, and look into a narrow garden bounded by the mountain to the east.  Pretty and colorful paintings adorn the outside walls of the tea-hut.

West.description: The tea room stands to the west.

rooms.name: Rice Fields
rooms.description: The fields stretch on in all directions, bounded only by the road to the west.  The fields are in excellent condition.  You wonder how many people live here, if they have this much land farmed.

North.description: The fields go far to the north.

East.description: The fields extend a short way to the east.

South.description: The fields go far to the south. Beyond that, you can see the city walls.

West.description: A road runs north-south just west of here.

rooms.name: Rice Fields
rooms.description: Your feet nearly slide in the muck!  You catch yourself.  That was close. You don't want to think about what's hidden by those sprightly green shoots. You've already felt something tickling your ankles as you walk.

North.description: The fields go as far north as your eye can see. On the horizon you can see a palace.

East.description: The fields end here in a crisply cut corner.

South.description: You see a hut standing here. Beyond it, you can see the city walls.

West.description: The fields go a short distance to the west. A road runs beyond them.

rooms.name: Rice Fields
rooms.description: This corner of the rice field butts up against a tall hedge of trees.  You stumble through the tall grass and almost knock yourself silly on one particularly tall tree.

South.description: The fields go far to the south. An unpainted hut stands in the distance, and beyond that, you see the city walls.

West.description: The fields extend to the west.

rooms.name: The Tea-House Katte
rooms.description: Though the tea-house is small, its kitchen is a marvel of orderly organization. Every single element has its own special place on the wooden counters and along the room's whitewashed walls. A cooking pit is set in one corner, oval stones ringing its small circumference. A low rack near the pit is hung with pots. Utensils hang neatly from pegs and hooks right below the pots. A pair of gauze towels are folded neatly on the countertop beside the cooking pit.

East.description: A quiet alcove attracts your attention.

extras.text: The towels are neatly embroidered with phoenixes. The initials "C S O" are incorporated into the phoenixes, and the name "AZKRAEL" in stylized glyphs that look like pictures.

rooms.name: The Alcove
rooms.description: As you go on your way, you pass the tokonoma, the art alcove.  Set into the wall, you see a niche.  You stop to admire the beautiful sculpture in the niche.  You can't tell what it is, but you like its graceful movement.  A window set into the east wall reveals a pretty orchard outside, and the wind whistles in through the opening.

North.description: You see the entrance to this little house.

South.description: You see the tea-room proper.

West.description: You see racks of pots and pans and kitchen equipment to your west.

rooms.name: The Cherry Tree Orchard
rooms.description: The pretty orchard beckons you further in.  You are walking by the side of the tea-house, nestled in its corner and staring up at the mountain's sheer side to your east.  The delicate pink flowers and tiny red cherries are a beautiful contrast to the green grass underfoot and the brown tree trunks.

North.description: The orchard continues to the north.

rooms.name: Rice Fields
rooms.description: As you travel this narrow part of the field, you feel distinctly unpopular. The people on the road to your immediate west are staring at you as if you were green-skinned.  The people working in the fields glower at you, clearly wanting you to get out of their fields before you destroy the delicate plants.

North.description: The fields extend to the north.

East.description: The fields end to the east, bordered by a stand of tall shrubs.

South.description: The fields extend to the south, as far as the eye can see.

West.description: The road runs north-south just west of here. Beyond that, you see lush, fertile farmlands.

rooms.name: Rice Fields
rooms.description: You feel your feet sink into the muck of the field.  You wonder if you'll EVER get your feet clean again.  You can see a beautiful garden over a gate to the east, but can't get to it.  Instead, you can go back to the rice fields to the north, south, or west.

North.description: The fields extend a short distance to the north.

South.description: The fields go far to the south, as far as your eye can see.

West.description: The fields go a short distance to the west. Beyond them, you see a road.

rooms.name: A Prayer-Tree Shrine
rooms.description: What a strange sight!  As you enter this quiet corner of the garden, you see a seemingly dead tree set into the middle of a well-tended shrine made of pretty pink stone.  Long bits of paper are folded into narrow strips and tied around the tree's branches.  You take one of the bits of paper and unroll it. You can't read the writing, but you can see the tearstains on it.  Perhaps it's a prayer of some sort.  That would make sense.  Looking around, you see the statue to your east, or you can go north.

North.description: You can hear a brook somewhere to your north. You see a graceful red-painted bridge -- perhaps the noise is, indeed, a brook.

East.description: You see a white marble statue standing to the east.

rooms.name: Kannon's Shrine
rooms.description: A tall, graceful statue adorns the shrine.  You circle the statue, admiring the flowers and grasses that grow around it in obvious deliberation.  The statue is of a woman, an impossibly beautiful and elegant woman, her hands stretched forward in supplication, with pain in her eyes.  You wonder what her story is.  Maybe the plaque below her will tell you more.

North.description: You see a stone lantern shrine to the north.

West.description: You see a very peculiar-looking tree to the west.

extras.text: The plaque reads: Dedicated to the Goddess of Mercy, who protects the Island of Odaishyozen from the terror of the seas.

rooms.name: The Entrance to the Tea-House
rooms.description: The tea house's foyer is quiet, hushed.  You enter quietly, whatever comments you were going to make dying on your lips.  The tea-house's walls are bare, unadorned clay, discolored in places.  The light comes in through small windows and through a skylight propped open with a carved staff of bamboo. The light is subdued, casting playful shadows on the walls and the tatami floor.  You can elect to head north, back to the walkway, or south, into the hut.

North.description: When you look north you see the Tea-House Gate - how did you miss it before?

South.description: You see a large alcove to the south.

rooms.name: The Cherry Tree Orchard
rooms.description: You stumble into a peaceful orchard, a neatly swept triple row of slender trees swaying in the breeze.  You stop and stare at the beauty of it all.  A clearing in the middle of the orchard seems custom built for relaxing and just watching the pretty scenery.

North.description: A peaceful pond lies to the north.

South.description: A pretty orchard stands to the south.

extras.text: You have never seen a more peaceful scene... The soft pink petals blow in the breeze, and sometimes you brush an errant petal from your clothes and face.

rooms.name: Rice Fields
rooms.description: Walking along this narrow stretch of the field, you can't help but notice how clean and meticulous the plants are.  Yes, it's muddy, and yes, your feet slide and are sucked down with every step, but the rows are neat and well manicured.  Perhaps it's because of the road to your immediate west.

North.description: The rice fields end to the north.

East.description: The rice fields end here, against a stand of lush shrubs.

South.description: The fields extend far, far to the south.

West.description: A road runs north-south here.

rooms.name: Rice Fields
rooms.description: You clog through the field, spirits almost brought down by the sheer unending tedium of the green shoots spreading their fingers to the sunshine. But it's so filled with life, so humid, so alive, that you can overlook that feeling for now.

North.description: A pond and a hut lie to the north.

South.description: The field extends far to the south, like a lush green carpet.

West.description: The field extends a bit to the south, and beyond that you see a road.

rooms.name: Against the Back of the Garden
rooms.description: You stand in the rear of the garden, on a pretty wooden bridge over a small bubbling brook that goes the length of the garden itself.  A crooked tree hangs over the brook, one graceful branch nearly dipping into the water.  Somewhere nearby a bird cries out.

North.description: The garden extends to the north.

East.description: A graceful stone lantern shrine stands to the east.

South.description: You see a most peculiar tree to the south.

rooms.name: The Teshoki-Ishi
rooms.description: You've noticed a preponderance of shrines here!  This one is a stone lantern, perpetually lit, even in the blinding sunlight beating down on the island.  The lantern is surrounded by flowers and grasses.  A few carved stone benches are set around the teshoki-ishi.  You feel like resting a few moments. The garden goes on in all directions.

North.description: You see the garden gate to the north.

East.description: The inner walk to the tea-house continues to the east.

South.description: A statue stands in the garden to the south.

West.description: You see a brook to the west.

rooms.name: The Uchi-Roji
rooms.description: The inner walk to the tea-house is beauty itself, sparse, but that only adds to its appeal.  You see the tsukubai, a stone basin with a little hollow in it you can wash your hands in; you can kneel beside the tsukubai on artfully arranged stones.  Water flows into the tsukubai, brought by a bamboo pipe, and overflows onto the stone-covered ground.  The koshikaki, backless benches, are set against the wall of the tea-house itself.  You wonder if you should wait here for the chajin, the tea master.

North.description: To the north you see the path to the tea-house.

East.description: The sound of water to the east catches your attention.

South.description: You see a black-lacquered gate to the south, and a thatch-roofed hut beyond.

West.description: You see a light source from the west. What is it?

rooms.name: The Koi Pond
rooms.description: The southern half of the koi pond is still, but not sluggish.  You can see the huge koi swimming in the pool, cavorting in the water to get to you as if they think you will feed them!  Beautiful flowers and large bonsai trees overhang the pool, interacting gracefully with the pool's clean curves and lines.

North.description: The pond continues to the north.

South.description: You see an orderly orchard full of pink blossoms.

West.description: You see a walkway to the west.

rooms.name: Rice Fields
rooms.description: The tall green rice plants don't quite hide the water flooding the field. The croaking of frogs and the buzzing of dragonflies lulls your senses.  Here and there birds wheel across the sky, dipping low to catch insects from the water.

North.description: You see a road to the north, and beyond that, a noisy bazaar.

East.description: A pond lies to the east.

South.description: The rice fields continue far to the south.

West.description: You see a road to the west. Beyond it, you see more green fields.

rooms.name: The Seeding Pond
rooms.description: You break through the rice fields to see a round shallow pond with a building next to it.  The building has no roof and bare windows with no glass or paper in them.  The pond is overhung with an old, thick-trunked tree.  Some ropes hanging from the tree's branches are tied to something in the water.

North.description: You see a road to the north. Far away, you see a magnificent palace rising into the sky.

South.description: The fields go as far to the south as your eye can see.

West.description: The fields go a short ways to the west.

extras.text: You think the ropes going from the tree are tied around a bale of hay, as odd as that sounds. The hay sprouts all over with delicate, finger-long rice plant seedlings. The bale is almost completely submerged under the pool.

rooms.name: A Quiet Corner of the Garden
rooms.description: The garden is quiet, except for the soft sounds of birds and the wind through the trees and grass.  Someone obviously spent a lot of time on this garden, because it's so serene, so perfect.  The gracefully arching trees bow over perfectly manicured grasses.  The pathstones are laid down with almost random order, yet you tread them easily, barely even noticing them.  Here and there a large rock breaks the monotony of trees and grasses.  You could spend all day here, just sitting on one of the rocks and looking at everything.

East.description: A walkway goes off to the east.

South.description: The garden extends to the south.

rooms.name: The Soto-Roji
rooms.description: As the gate closes behind you, your breath is taken away by the lush garden before you.  A small building, almost a shed, is hung with pegs for your coat and extraneous belongings.  Its roof overhangs a bench built into the side of the shed.  Cushions on the bench invite you to take your ease for a moment, before the chajin comes to greet you.  A path laid with flat walking stones continues to the east, or you can continue to wander the garden to the west and south.  Or, were you mad, you could leave the garden complex to the north.

North.description: You see that the hedge on the other side is merely the disguise for a garden gate!

East.description: A pathway runs to the east here.

South.description: A stone lantern is lit to the south.

West.description: The garden extends to the west.

rooms.name: The Roji Path
rooms.description: The path continues from the gate to the tea house.  As you tread the carefully random stones, you look around eagerly.  The hedge blocks your view of whatever is outside.  You hear a sweet bubbling pond to your east.  The roji continues to the west, or you can head further south on the path or east to the koi pond.

East.description: You see a marvellous pond to the east.

South.description: You see a simple walkway to the south.

West.description: You see a small building near the garden's gate.

rooms.name: The Koi Pond
rooms.description: As you traverse the huge pond, you are struck with how orderly, how sweetly graceful, the garden wraps around it.  You look with admiration at pretty flowers all around the border of the pond.  The trees arch over the pond's clear surface.  In the center of the pond stands a statue of a beautiful girl, the water flowing and parting around it.

South.description: The pond continues to the south.

West.description: A stone pathway begins to the west.

extras.text: The statue seems to be made of yellow gemstone; its facets glitter in the light of the sun. The statue is a figure of a young girl, her hair slicked back by water and flying behind her. You can tell that whoever built this pond had to have a lot of money to afford this gem-sculpture!

rooms.name: The Intersection of Kitayama Row and Sumisara Way
rooms.description: This bustling intersection has an overwhelming activity level. Golden- skinned short people jostle each other as they go through here with their packages and satchels, staring at strangers with open curiosity. Carriages with garishly silk-clad noblemen and womn in them slow down as strangers go past, then speed up again. Farmers leading beasts mingle openly with the rest of the traffic. Over the people's heads, a marketplace is visible to the north. Kitayama Row continues to the east and west, and Sumisara Way leads south through the fields toward the city walls, dimly visible far away.

North.description: You see a noisy, jostling bazaar straight ahead.

East.description: The road continues to the east.

South.description: Kitayama Row extends far to the south.

West.description: The road continues to the west.

rooms.name: Kitayama Row
rooms.description: A busy, wide road runs east-west through a small city.  To the south, green, swampy fields are visible.  To the north, sturdy stone walls prevent passage. Laughter and voices are audible coming from the building there, but everywhere else, people work and talk much more quietly. Emerald hills cloaked in mist rise up beyond the city, while to the south, the grey city walls encircle the area to embrace those hills.

East.description: Far to the east, you see that the road ends in rubble.

South.description: The lush, fertile rice fields extend far to the south.

West.description: Kitayama Row extends far to the west, ending in rubble.

rooms.name: Kitayama Row
rooms.description: A well-kept road runs from east to west here, passing by rice fields to the south and toward a gate that looms to the north before a magnificent palace with a peaked red roof. The people who pass through here are of all qualities and stations, with everything from puissant warrior-nobles all the way down to peasant farmers in drab linen smocks and pants. The best-dressed head north toward the gate, where laughter and loud music can be heard.

North.description: You see an utterly unadorned, open gate standing to the north. A palace stands behind it.

East.description: The road continues far to the east.

South.description: The rice fields extend far to the south.

West.description: The road continues for a short distance to the west.

rooms.name: Kitayama Row
rooms.description: Running east and west, this street is one of the main ones of the city. It passes rice fields to the south, green and growing in warm seasons, while skirting a palace's walls to the north. Feminine laughter and exotic music come from there. People walk past on the road, with nobles and peasant farmers trying not to mingle as they pass each other. The city itself nestles in a valley, with emerald hills shrouded in mist all around its close-set buildings with their peaked roofs of red tile.

East.description: The road extends far to the east.

South.description: The rice fields continue for a short distance to the south.

West.description: The road ends nearby to the west.

rooms.name: The End of Kitayama Row
rooms.description: Kitayama Row ends here, in the road's general dwindling into a field of wildflowers and grasses. Beyond that, a rocky hillside rises up devoid of cultivation. To the south, a tall wooden amphitheatre with no roof can be seen, a short path leading towards it. The road extends to the east for some distance. The city itself is very meticulous and clearly planned. Its city walls can be seen to the south far away encircling the area.

East.description: The street continues to the east.

South.description: You hear laughter and voices talking south of here.

rooms.name: Kitayama Row
rooms.description: This is the eastern half of Kitayama Row.  The short road extends east and west, with rice fields to the south.  A fence separates the road from the market to the north.

East.description: The road extends a short distance to the east.

South.description: Fertile green rice fields extend far to the south.

West.description: The intersection of two roads lies directly to the west.

rooms.name: Kitayama Row
rooms.description: Kitayama Row goes to the east and west here.  You look around.  The cobbled street is clean and well-cared for, with lanterns at regular intervals.  The crowded street is filled with people walking.  Sometimes you catch a glimpse of brightly embroidered cloth, surely the clothing of a nobleman or noblewoman. You notice some of them heading for a beautiful gate to the north.

North.description: A golden gate flanked by two golden lions stands to the north -- it's magnificent.

East.description: The road continues a short way to the east.

South.description: You see a pond with a large tree hanging over it to your south.

West.description: The road continues far to the west. You see an intersection close by.

rooms.name: Kitayama Row
rooms.description: This wide road extends to the east and west.  A tall wall obscures vision to the north, and an equally tall hedge seems impassible to the south.  A fence to the east appears to be a break in the hedge.

East.description: The road ends nearby to the east.

West.description: The road continues far to the west.

rooms.name: The End of Kitayama Row
rooms.description: Kitayama Row ends here, rather abruptly, as if someone building the road suddenly decided to stop here.  But you see, through the hedge, a way south into a beautiful garden.

South.description: You suddenly feel intensely interested in going south, but a hedge seems to be blocking you.

rooms.name: The Sumiya
rooms.description: The Sumiya, the great gate to the Shimabara, stands here.  The gate is huge, almost fortress-like, with no carvings, no pretty pictures, no ornamentation at all.  However, the facade just beyond the gate is resplendent with rich slats and railings, though it also has no carving or ornamentation.  An entrance just wide enough for two opens in the middle of the facade to the north.

North.description: A gate separates you from the clean, elegant courtyard ahead.

South.description: South of you, you see a well-kept road, and beyond that, lush green fields.

rooms.name: The Peasant Courtyard
rooms.description: The courtyard of Shimabara is the entrance to a floating world, populated by those brave souls who can live for the moment, and ignore the outer world and its strict structure, its harsh insistence on honor and responsibility. Graceful bonsai trees, small and twisting, grow in wooden pots all around the periphery of the elegant courtyard, bending gracefully over colored grasses and wildflowers. The tightly-fitted hexagonal stones of the ground are scrupulously clean and shiny. Quiet conversation in exotic tones wafts through the air from the various visitors here, mingling with a scent of wildflowers and perfume. A bar is visible to the north, and the street runs to the south.

North.description: You hear loud singing to the north.

South.description: A very strong gate stands here.

West.description: A door carved with lotus blossoms stands to the west. A sweet scent emanates from behind it.

rooms.name: The Sakeya
rooms.description: The bar is rowdy, raucous and jovial. Beautiful but haggard women gracefully bow and weave with trays of small ceramic cups and tangy seafood plates among loud, gesturing guests. The strains of a foreign instrument rise through the voices to linger on the air, though the music sounds more like silverware being dropped. Some of the more inebriated guests are howling a bawdy tune to it. Kitchens lie to the east, an outdoor garden to the north, and the establishment's courtyard just to the south.

North.description: You can smell the beer north of here, there's so much of it.

East.description: You smell something good coming from the east!

South.description: A courtyard opens southward.

rooms.name: A Brightly-Lit Katte
rooms.description: Serving-girls dodge intruders on their way in and out of this brightly-lit kitchen. During the day, sunshine spills in through a skylight. At night, lamps keep everything lit with bright golden light. The kitchen itself is very well-organized, with pots stacked neatly in shelves against one wall near a huge pit that blazes with a cooking-fire. Teapots hang from hooks above it. A vast iron cauldron simmers on the fire at all times, with unfamiliar scents rising from it--fish, vegetables, and an odd tang. The Sakeya lies westward.

West.description: The loud singing is still going on to the west.

rooms.name: The Biergarten
rooms.description: Long tables are lit by hundreds of little lamps set along their smooth surfaces. Male guests crowd around them, lifting tankards and small ceramic cups. At random moments, they break into song and occasionally dance with each other. Most of them are dressed in decent but not extravagant clothing. An archway leads to the east, to a garden, and another way out lies southward.

East.description: You see a garden to the east. It's quiet and darker than this noisy public room.

South.description: The bar's serving room lies to the south.

rooms.name: The Gate to Akusho
rooms.description: The gate to Akusho, supposedly a place of evil, is beautifully carved with lotus flowers and vines. A scent of perfume and essential oils wafts through it. Music and voices can be heard past the gate, but all that is visible are some peaked roofs rising above the gate's arch. The gates open to the east, but a coatroom is visible to the north and a receiving room lies to the west.

East.description: You see a door carved with lotus blossoms.

West.description: You see a sparsely furnished room with tatami-mat floors to the west.

rooms.name: The Receiving Room
rooms.description: This corner of the elite pleasure-house Akusho is floored with delicate tatami-reed mats, like most of the villa.  The room is spacious, with very little furniture or decorations.  Though it is clearly a receiving room of some sort, there are no couches, nor tables or chairs.  A large black and white painting adorns one wall.  Shoji screens, elegantly and intricately carved, block off the south wall, though a hallway starts to the north.

North.description: You see a hallway to the north. It feels a little chilly.

East.description: You see a gate carved with lotus blossoms and vines, standing in a small foyer of some kind.

rooms.name: The Coat Room
rooms.description: This is a small, square-shaped room set about its walls with hooks carved like dragon heads, each one set enough apart from its fellows to comfortably settle a bulky garment onto. Packages and boxes are set on the floor among the cloaks. The gate lies southward, and a long hallway begins to the west. The air smells lightly of incense and perfume.

South.description: The room you're in opens into a small room with a door carved in lotus blossoms.

West.description: You see a foyer that curves into a long hallway.

extras.text: Some of the coats and cloaks seem quite expensive compared to the others you've seen people wear here. The packages arranged neatly at the bottom of the coatrack are wrapped in a variety of brightly coloured papers, tied with clean white string. One has something written on it, but you can't read the alien letters.

rooms.name: The Hallway Foyer
rooms.description: A long hallway begins here and leads off to the north. The wooden floor is cool and glossy with decades if not centuries of patient waxing. The hallway is cramped, clearly intended for short people to walk through. Low wide windows to the west look out over a wild-seeming stretch of grass, flowers, and trees. From here the hallway branches to the north, south, or east.

North.description: The hallway continues to the north.

East.description: Lots of coats and cloaks are hung on pegs in this small coatroom.

South.description: You see a sparsely furnished room with a tatami mat floor.

rooms.name: Hallway
rooms.description: The hallway stretches north to south.  The ancient wooden floor, dark and shiny with countless polishing, leads off into the darkness.  Even in the brightest sunshine, this room would be subdued, barely lit.  There are no torches in the walls, no other light sources that you can see.  You hear delicate music coming from the west, past an open door.

North.description: The hallway continues to the north. The walls are ornamented with black and white paintings.

South.description: The hallway continues to the south. Beyond that, you see a plain, sparsely furnished room.

West.description: You see a high-ceilinged room to the west. You hear music coming from it.

rooms.name: The Hallway
rooms.description: The hallway of the main building, Akusho, goes from north to south.  Your footsteps echo on the wood of the floor no matter how quietly you walk.  The hall is silent, except for that.  The dim lights barely illumine the walls, bare except for an occasional painting, plainly framed in dark wood.  To the east you see an open door carved with lotuses.

North.description: The hallway continues to the north, ending a short distance away.

East.description: A door stands here.

South.description: The hallway continues to the south.

rooms.name: The Hallway
rooms.description: The hallway goes from north to south.  You are impressed with the delicately rendered ink paintings on the walls, in black, white, and usually one other color -- the lack of color just seems to accentuate what little color is in the paintings.  More low windows to the west look out upon a wild bit of forest before the sharp rise of the mountains.  You see an open door to your east that is carved with butterflies.

North.description: The hallway ends to the north.

East.description: A door stands here.

South.description: The hallway continues a good distance to the south.

rooms.name: The Hallway's End
rooms.description: The sweet sweep of the hallway ends here.  A single soft-lit window looks out on the sharp arch of the mountains outside, and the tangled growth between it and the Akusho.  Another looks out to the west.  You see to the east another door, this one carved with herons, a gracious arch to their fragile forms.

East.description: A door stands here.

South.description: The hall extends far to the south.

rooms.name: The Performance Hall
rooms.description: The room is large, and the acoustics astounding.  Maybe it's the wooden floors, or the gracefully arched roof above, with its skylights to let in gentle sunshine.  A double row of wooden pillars marks off a center strip of the room that is clearly a performing area, with polished wooden floors and lots of room to move.  The rows on either side of this center strip are tatami-lined, obviously intended to be sat upon by guests watching someone perform in the middle section. The area is very subdued-looking, certainly not bawdy or risque. Paper-lined windows let in muted light to the south, and exits lead north to an audience section or east to a hallway.

North.description: You can see an audience section to the north.

East.description: You see a hallway running north-south to the east.

West.description: An elegantly carved wooden door seems almost hidden behind some draperies.

rooms.name: Audience Seating
rooms.description: This large chamber, high-ceilinged and airy, is floored with soft tatami-reed mats.  White stone pillars mark off the boundary between the audience section and a center strip that is made of shiny wood.  Another audience section, this one much smaller, is located to the south next to the strip of wooden floor.

South.description: You can go south to the performance hall.

rooms.name: Yoshino's Office
rooms.description: You carefully pick your way through the dark doorway to see the offices of the proprietress of Shimabara, Yoshino.  Her gracious, gentle, and unbearably intelligent personality are marked everywhere, from the bare desk built into the wall and set so low to the floor the user would have to kneel directly on the floor, to the staggered shelves on the walls with their delicate keepsakes on it--fragile glass flowers, origami figurines so real looking you almost reach out to touch them, a few thin books bound in embroidered covers, a quill pen with a golden tip.  You can go back east to the performance hall.

East.description: The door you just opened doesn't seem nearly as beautifully carved from this direction!

South.description: The door is right next to the desk, to the south. You can barely make out a doorknob of some sort in the dim light.

rooms.name: Yoshino's Quarters
rooms.description: The room is large and obviously appointed by someone with taste and a whole lot of money, but the furnishings are sparse and well-chosen: a low wooden bed with tons of fluffy featherbeds on it, a nightstand, a huge double-doored closet with doorknobs carved with dragonflies and herons, and, tucked into one corner, a recessed shrine with a statue of a beautiful, sad woman on a pedestal.  A few paintings of plants and animals adorn the walls: cranes flying, flowers with bright petals set against grey mountains, and other beautiful sights.

North.description: A plain, unornamented door blocks your way north.

rooms.name: The Lotus Room
rooms.description: The room is darker than the rest of the Akusho.  An understated, yet riveting, painting of a lotus arrests your attention.  The painting overhangs a carved fourposter bed.  A low table set under a window invites guests to sit right on the tatami mat if they like.  A steaming teapot sits on the table, with two handle-less white cups beside it.

West.description: A door stands here.

rooms.name: The Butterfly Room
rooms.description: This room is sunny, cheerful, and warm, with a friendly feel to it.  The fourposter bed is covered in white linen, almost glowing with the sunshine coming in through a muted skylight.  A table set with fresh tea is set so low to the floor that no chairs are necessary -- you could kneel or sit down and eat or drink comfortably.  Pretty, colorful paintings hang on the white-painted walls.  The only door stands to the west.

West.description: A door stands here.

rooms.name: The Heron Room
rooms.description: The scent of unknown incense fills your nose as you enter this room.  The room is dark, lit by a red paper lantern dimly.  The light barely lets you make out the low bed made with red satin sheets that dominates the room.  Black and white ink paintings of mountains, mounted on scrolls, are hung here and there. You think you hear a low, throbbing music coming from somewhere in the room.

West.description: Through an open doorway you see a hallway.

rooms.name: The Fishmonger's Stall
rooms.description: The raucous vendor's stall is filled with tanks of water, huge tanks filled with fish of every description: small and delicate red-and-orange ones, huge and meaty silver ones, black ones with eyes on tentacles, anything you can imagine, all swimming around like they know and don't care that they're going to be someone's dinner very soon.  A fishmonger cuts fish into sashimi for customers, using a sharp knife and a practiced eye. Archways lead north and east from here.

North.description: You see a shop to the north.

East.description: The entrance to the market lies to the east.

rooms.name: The Entrance to the Market
rooms.description: The wide gates open to reveal a whole other world: People jostling, talking all at once, laden with packages of various kinds, and the smells!  Food, drinks, the smoky tang of fish, that distinctive miso broth that is the basis for Odaishyozen soups, unfamiliar salty-sharp scents that tantalize and tempt. All manner of men are here, some wearing the double swords that mark the noble warriors who live here, followed by servants carrying paper-wrapped parcels. There are very few women here, varying from the young and common to the old and obviously wealthy.  From here, the market extends north, east, or west, with the street visible to the south.

North.description: You hear loud clanging noises to the north, and smell burning metal.

East.description: You see a dress-shop to the east.

South.description: The street runs east-west just south of here.

West.description: You can smell the scent of fish from the west.

rooms.name: The Dressmaker's Shop
rooms.description: Perfectly-spaced racks of exquisite silk robes hang here, in neat aisles with plenty of room to move. The floor is covered in a woven carpet in a fantastic floral design in colors of sunset and dark blue, its colors accented by the wall hangings and paintings. Very well-dressed men and women filter through, examining the embroidered and dyed silks without touching them. An archway leads west from here.

West.description: You see the entrance to the market to the west.

rooms.name: The Ceramicsmith's Shop
rooms.description: The shop is lined with wooden plank shelves, with pots, cups, and other ceramic wares. Aisles are wedged into the place somehow, making progress difficult. Every horizontal surface available is covered in ceramicware. Everything here is simple but of high quality, with little thought given to security or potential theft. The main counter, indeed, is out of sight of most of the shop. The walls and floors are quite clean, with no decorations save for a curious ink painting on silk of a bird on a leafless branch. The shop can be exited through archways to the east and south.

East.description: You smell hot metal to the east, and hear clanging noises.

South.description: You can smell lots of fish to the south.

rooms.name: The Swordsmith's Shop
rooms.description: This noisy, clanging, sooty shop is clean and organized, but a thin coat of black dust clings to everything. Various swords hang on the walls on fine wooden display racks, their heft, weight, and balance noted in a foreign script. Other weapons, all exotic, hang on other racks and displays--halberds, pikes, and shortswords. Most of them are gracious and simple in design, though some are intricately engraved with scrollwork. The shop itself is large enough to accommodate the workbench to the side and the double-width archway leading out to the forge itself, visible to the east.

North.description: You see another shop to the north, past the crowds of people.

South.description: The entrance to the bazaar lies to the south.

West.description: You see another shop to the west.

rooms.name: The Rice Shop
rooms.description: Small and crowded, this shop contains racks of bins of all sorts of rice. Each bin contains a multitude of dusty, pale white or cream grains, each with a wide scoop to ladle it into containers for sale. A counter that is little more than a simple table and chair is set against the rear wall, and that is where sales take place. There are likely two dozen completely different types of rice for sale here, including prepared rice balls.

South.description: You can hear a forge to the south.

rooms.name: A Quiet Garden to the Side
rooms.description: A wide, arching trellis leads into a quiet, subdued garden. Ferns and grasses grow wild-looking, tall enough to brush at the legs of those entering the garden. In the middle of it, a fountain fed by a bamboo tube babbles in the semi-light filtering in through the trees from the brightly- lit buildings around it. A wooden bench, plain and austere, allows a visitor to sit down to enjoy the peace and quiet. The only visible exit lies through the archway to the west.

West.description: The spell of serenity is broken when you look west, and hear the loud singing!

rooms.name: Outside the Palace Gate
rooms.description: If you thought the Yomeimon Gate was beautiful, then this one takes your breath away.  Lions made of gold stand sentinel at the very front of the gate, at the first archway.  You marvel at the gems set into their eyes, indeed, set into the doors, and arches, and panels, that apparently are in no danger of being stolen.  What kind of society is this, that crusts public gates with gems and gold without care of thievery?

North.description: The beautiful roadway ahead is impeded only by the beautiful gate ahead of you!

South.description: A paved road runs east-west just south of here.

rooms.name: Inside the Palace Gate
rooms.description: You marvel at the thick, tall gate entranceway that seems to mark the boundary between heaven and earth: As you walk the shell driveway, you seem to be in a whole other world from the busy street to the south.  Pretty grasses and flowers line the edge of the gate.  You can go north, to a large driveway, or south, back to the gate.

North.description: The path up to the palace continues to the north.

South.description: A beautiful wooden gate blocks your way back south.

rooms.name: The Carriage Approach
rooms.description: The walkway to the south ends here, in a spacious area bounded by a low fence on all sides and the gate to the south.  To the east stands a small building that obviously is intended to store carriages and such.  To the west, the courtyard begins.

East.description: The path goes up to a small, well-made stable.

South.description: You see the palace gates to the south.

West.description: A courtyard lies just west of here.

rooms.name: The Outer Courtyard
rooms.description: The courtyard is graciously appointed, looking more like a wild garden with a stone walkway than anything else.  Small trees line its periphery.  You look around...  The courtyard stretches for quite some space before it finally ends in a covered walkway, so distinctive of this castle, to the north, or you can go east to the carriage approach.

North.description: A walkway begins to the north.

East.description: A carriage house and stable stands to the east.

rooms.name: A Walkway
rooms.description: A walkway begins right here, emerging out of the path from the south, heading to the north.  The walkway is covered with a wooden roof.  The floors are ancient wood, and do not creak under your feet, they are so old and settled.  You can hear your very breath echoing here, though.  The walkway is almost a tunnel.  The only thing, in fact, that makes you think it's not is the dim light filtering in through either end of it.  Murals of a fantastic Sea Serpent adorn the walls.  You think the story, and the walkway, continue to the north, or you can go south to the courtyard again.

North.description: The walkway to the palace continues to the north.

South.description: A courtyard lies to the south.

extras.text: You marvel at the magnificent talent and skills of whoever painted these murals. In sparse, unsparing brushstrokes, the story is told. Humans and gods and fantastic beasts are almost a side interest beside fabulous vistas and incredible backdrops of mountains, oceans, storms, and howling winds. The Sea Serpent figures in rather prominently, its bulky form blotting out the sun as it towers above the comparably puny walled city of Odaishyozen. The glowing figure of a beautiful woman stands before it, arms outstretched as if to stop it single-handedly. She stands on the wall of the city, her black hair streaming out behind her, her robes plastered to her body in the storm.

rooms.name: The Path Beside the Stream
rooms.description: The covered walkway opens a little here.  One wall has been removed so you can enjoy the beautiful stream winding through the property.  Huge koi fish swim in the streams, testament to someone's fabulous wealth.  Across the other wall, you see the story of the Sea Serpent, and see it destroying a walled city.  However, you have no idea why.  You can go further north, to the large house there, or south to the rest of the walkway.

North.description: Looking north, you see a metal openwork gate.

South.description: A covered walkway extends to the south.

rooms.name: The Entrance to the Tozamurai
rooms.description: The house is high-roofed, with its arching tiles reaching the sky itself, and skylights letting the sunshine in. Inside is the careless clutter of eternal bachelors. Obviously a living area for men of a certain rank, its entrance belies its clutter and its air of camaraderie.  Pictures line the walls, and plants in wooden pots guard them. Soft music comes from someplace nearby. A door open to a receiving room lies westward, and food smells come from the east. Another entrance lies northward.

South.description: Southward, you see the main path from Kitayama Row, blocked by the gate.

West.description: A receiving room with cushions on the floors lies to the west.

rooms.name: The Carriage House
rooms.description: The building is small and somehow spacious.  Hay on the floor crackles under your feet as you enter, tickling your nose, and bits of dust swirl in the light from some skylights above.  Carrels for small carriages are built into the walls.  You see some carriages in some of them, some somber, some brightly painted.  Birds sing above you in the rafters.  You can go back west to the courtyard and carriage approach, but that's all.

West.description: The carriage approach lies to the west.

rooms.name: The Warriors' Dining Hall
rooms.description: Half a dozen long tables are arranged in neat rows, forming a central aisle in the hall's center and two narrow ones at its sides. Spice containers sit on each table, carefully set in the center of each white tablecloth. The air smells of salty, fishy, briny scents. During the day, sunshine streams in through skylights and white-paper-covered windows. A kitchen lies eastward, but another archway leads to the west.

North.description: You see lots of beds to the north.

East.description: You smell good food to the east -- unfamiliar, tangy scents that make you hungry.

West.description: A building's entranceway lies to the west.

rooms.name: The Shoin (Receiving Room)
rooms.description: The receiving room is spacious, with cushions on the floor that invite you to sink to your weary knees.  The pictures on the wall are of flowers and animals -- hardly what you expected from the house of warriors.  But you can't help but notice how the walls are scarred, as if from sword-cuts.  You think to yourself that perhaps these warriors aren't so weak after all.  You can go north, to the source of the gentle music, or east.

North.description: You see a small nook with statues and paintings in it.

East.description: An entranceway lies to the east. Beyond it, you see an open door leading to a kitchen.

rooms.name: The Oshiita (Art Room)
rooms.description: The art room!  You enter, and your soul sings.  Sculpture in recessed alcoves beckons you to come and lose yourself in contemplation.  Softly lit pictures of history, of the natural world's splendor, of people past and present, line the walls.  Somewhere you hear music, soft and lulling.  The treasures in this room alone make you wonder about Odaishyozen.  What kind of people put their most beautiful treasures out for public display like this? Nothing is even guarded.  They must be powerful indeed, these warriors, to be so confident in their name that they don't guard their wealth.

East.description: You see a study to the east.

South.description: You see a sparsely furnished room with cushions arranged carefully on the floor.

West.description: A corridor begins to the west.

rooms.name: A Private Study
rooms.description: Here is where the samurai retainers of the Shogun and the Emperor do their thinking.  Scroll-books line the shelves on the walls, containing the wisdom of the land.  Cushions sit next to low desks that are little more than raised panels of the floor.  One of two of these 'desks' are built into the windowsills, letting sunshine spill in shyly.

East.description: You see a sleeping area with lots of beds in it.

South.description: This building's foyer stands to the south.

West.description: A room full of sculpture and paintings lies westward.

rooms.name: The Samurai's Dormitory
rooms.description: The room is dark, filled with flat beds that are little more than featherbeds on the floor.  You count about thirty of them.  This room is littered with knives, belts, wigs on stands, and other manly accoutrements. Oddly, you see no clothes.  The clothes must be in the closets lining the walls.

South.description: A dining hall with long tables lies southward.

West.description: A handsomely appointed study lies to the west.

rooms.name: A Corridor
rooms.description: You almost stumble into the corridor.  Further examination reveals that this is because the floor is slightly higher than that of the previous room.  It must be some kind of add-on.  Now that you look further, in fact, you can see that this corridor is another of those covered walkways connecting two buildings.  Outside, through a window, you see the sharp mountain and its wildland foothills.  The Shikidai rises above you to the north, or you can go to the Tozamurai to the east.

North.description: The corridor ends at another building's entranceway.

East.description: A room full of beautiful sculpture and paintings lies to the east.

rooms.name: The Entrance to the Shikidai
rooms.description: This room was intended purely for receiving the Emperor's guests.  You look around in wonder, admiring his taste and wealth.  The floors are sweet smelling tatami mats.  The walls, pure white, to reflect the sunshine pouring in.  The ceilings are raftered with clean wood in a pretty and utterly logical arrangement that somehow appeals to your sense of aesthetics.  The Shikidai goes on to the north and east.

North.description: A very plain room lies to the north. You can see that its floor is made of tightly-woven reeds.

rooms.name: The Secretary's Study
rooms.description: You step into a room of order and paperwork.  Clearly it belongs to a secretary of some kind.  The desk built into the wall is filled with drawers and little bitty cubbyholes.  Papers litter the desktop.  Perhaps the secretary got called away and had to leave his things here.

North.description: A lounge of some kind lies northward. You can see small round tables in it, but no chairs.

West.description: You can head south, to a short corridor, which curves away.

rooms.name: The Gedan
rooms.description: The audience chamber begins here, with the lowest of the three levels leading to the emperor.  Sliding doors painted gold, with trees and birds, slide open to reveal the familiar tatami floors.  Windows line the walls, a continuous line of sunshine-filled squares.  Other than that, the Gedan is bare.  You can head north or south from here.

North.description: The audience chamber begins to the north. Oddly, it seems as if the next part of the audience chamber is built on a slightly raised platform.

South.description: The building's entranceway stands to the south.

rooms.name: The Tea Lounge
rooms.description: The room is filled with small round tables set very low to the ground.  You could sit at a small table and rest your feet in the pit below each table.  A vase with a single flower in it adorns each table.  A large bar rests against one side of the room.

North.description: A connecting walkway stretches northward. You can't see anything beyond it.

South.description: You see a small room with a desk and simple chair to the south.

rooms.name: The Connecting Walkway
rooms.description: You go through this walkway quietly, noting the ancient wood.  This covered walkway connects the Emperor's offices and apartments with the Shikidai.  You are honored to be here at all.  The exquisite lotus blossom carvings on the wood panelling, the fine fretwork of the shoji doors at either end of hall, all of it, convinces you of the majesty and simplicity of the Emperor, which is the intended effect anyhow.

North.description: You see a sparsely-furnished room to the north -- but the delicate paintings and carved wooden panelling speaks for itself.

South.description: You see a serene lounge to the south. A few small very low-set tables are carefully arranged in the room.

rooms.name: The Emperor's Private Receiving Rooms
rooms.description: The entrance to the Emperor's private rooms, the Kuroshoin, is as understated as the Emperor himself.  Apparently, people in Odaishyozen don't like furniture much.  Shelves housing scroll-books, just one or two of them artfully arranged with bonsai trees, line one wall.  You don't notice anything else here.  You do, however, notice the door north.

North.description: A handsome chamber lies to the north.

South.description: You see a wooden-floored walkway to the south.

rooms.name: An Audience Chamber
rooms.description: The door leading into the room is carved with cranes, lions, and other fantastic beasts.  Tatami mats cover the floor.  The sunshine pours in through open window panels.  Birds sing outside.  Inside, the square balance posts are carved with more birds.  You could swear that if you reached out, you'd touch feathers, they are so lifelike.  From here, you can go south to the entrance to the Kuroshoin or east to its opposite end.

East.description: You see gold-and-silver painted walls framing an otherwise bare room.

South.description: A receiving room lies to the south.

rooms.name: A Cherry-Blossom Room
rooms.description: The walls are painted with gold and silver, to depict a fabulous orchard of trees, with red stones of some kind forming the cherries themselves.  It's the most ostentatious thing you've ever seen.  You look around, thinking that surely, this last room will contain something interesting.  You notice a little cubbyhole, but that's about it.

East.description: When you look east, you see an opulent, carved door that almost melts in against the gold-painted walls.

West.description: A sunny room lies westward.

extras.text: A vase is inside the cubbyhole. The vase is carved and painted with flowers and birds, of such a realistic and lifelike nature that if it weren't for their fantastic appearance you'd swear some artist had somehow put real flowers and birds on the vase. It has a few plants in it -- some long, thin shoots ending in exotic and obscure-seeming spearhead-shaped flowers, and some kind of bare fern.

rooms.name: Entrance to the Royal Chambers
rooms.description: You enter the Emperor's royal chambers, his sanctum sanctorum.  Wild birds fly in and out through the open shoji doors.  To the north, the river flows into the mountain itself, but you can't reach it from here.  A narrow strip of embroidered silk on the floor leads to the east and west.

East.description: A sumptuous, cushioned room lies to the east.

West.description: West of you is a beautiful, polished door that is almost obscured by the gold-covered decorations on the walls.

rooms.name: The Emperor's Lounge
rooms.description: An opulent, gilded room, covered in cushions from wall to wall, greets your eyes.  Incense burns in one corner, suffusing the room with honeysuckle and jasmine scents.  Here is where the Emperor relaxes when he is not in council or at the theatre or in his garden, and it's obvious that he takes relaxation seriously.  You could snuggle into the cushions, or maybe you'd rather take the silk ribbon trail south or west.

South.description: The room south contains a simple wooden bed and a few other pieces of furniture.

West.description: The entrance to the Emperor's suites lies to the west.

rooms.name: The Music Room
rooms.description: The walls are acoustic, you can tell.  You admire the carvings in the walls that seem to throw back every sound you make.  The tatami mats give way to a strip of bare polished wood running in a strip down the length of the room, where performers obviously work their magic for people sitting in the rows on either side.

East.description: A bedroom lies to the east.

extras.text: As you look outside, you are thunderstruck with the beauty of a tiny pocket garden. At once wild and manicured, it rolls in all directions. You can see a fountain of some sort, and a shrine.

rooms.name: The Emperor's Sleeping Chambers
rooms.description: You don't know what you expected of the sleeping quarters of the Emperor, but this is certainly different.  The bed is huge, yes, but simple, being a simple featherbed atop a wooden frame, just like any other person's.  The room is huge and nearly empty except for the bed and a sitting area in one corner, lined with cushions and mats.  A small table set low to the ground occupies another corner.  On the table you see incense burning.  The Emperor must be somewhere nearby.  Or maybe he's just very forgetful.

North.description: You see an entertainment area to the north.

South.description: The open air flows across your body gently. A platform extends across a serene pond.

West.description: You see a high-ceilinged room, its floor a tatami mat.

rooms.name: The Moon-Viewing Platform
rooms.description: The view here is incredible.  One entire wall is missing, exposed to the air, the better to enjoy the small lake it perfectly frames. From the bedroom just north of here, the floor extends to the south for a short distance. Several varieties of exquisitely-pruned trees, most of them smaller than the norm for their respective species, line the pond, while a single rock rises up from just slightly off-center in the water itself to make an elegant argument for asymmetry. Colorful silk cushions in sunset-orange, black, and midnight blue are arranged just so on the platform. A beautiful garden can be seen to the west.

North.description: You see a large, simple bed to the north.

South.description: The wall south is entirely missing, but you can't go that way because the platform ends.

West.description: The wooden platform melts into the entranceway of a well-tended garden. A path winds through it.

extras.text: The room is open-ended, with one wall entirely missing. The construction, however, seems deliberate. You can easily see the pond south of the room, elegant and utterly simplistic in its lines and form. You can only imagine how beautiful it must look when the moon is shining perfectly in the center of that missing wall.

rooms.name: The Katte
rooms.description: It's a kitchen fit for a roving pack of bachelor samurai: huge, utterly foolproof, and stocked with all kinds of portable-looking goodies.  Pots and pans, huge and unwieldy, line a shelf along one wall.  Someone has tried very hard to clean the spatters from the walls and floor, and the countertops are tidy, but overall there's a tenuous sense that hideous disaster could be unleashed at any time.

East.description: Shelves line the room to the east. Foodstuffs fill the shelves.

West.description: The dining hall lies westward.

rooms.name: The Pantries
rooms.description: Again, a pantry fit for a lot of bachelor warriors living free of civilizing restrictions.  The shelves are wide and deep, and although someone has taken care to at least keep things tidy, you can see sheer chaos about to erupt. There doesn't appear to be any other entrance beside the one to the kitchens.

West.description: You see the kitchen area to the west.

rooms.name: The Pond
rooms.description: It's tranquil, quiet, and utterly peaceful.  Almost round, but not quite, even its imperfection makes it more perfect.  Trees line the edge of the pond, their gnarled trunks reaching up to the sky.  Fish swim in the pond, lazily flicking their fins as they go.  One perfect stone pokes up from not quite the center of the lake.  Its asymmetry draws your eye to the tiny oak tree whose lowest branch just barely skims the pond's placid surface.

West.description: A lush garden begins here and extends a short distance to the west.

rooms.name: The Emperor's Garden
rooms.description: The Emperor's garden is lush; every step draws you closer and closer into a world of quiet reverie.  It doesn't, however, look like other gardens.  This garden is not designed to be the center of attention.  This garden is designed to distract your mind from external cares so you can concentrate on the internal world.  This particular part of the garden is a quiet corner bounded on two sides by the palace.  The garden continues to the south and east.

East.description: The garden continues to the east.

South.description: You see a white alabaster fountain nestled in the garden.

rooms.name: The Emperor's Garden
rooms.description: A path of artfully-placed stones leads in a winding route through the lush green garden. Flowers, bushes, and trees grow in profusion here, each perfectly accenting its neighbors. Nooks contain large vases of fruit trees or sculptures in ornate, stylized designs. The palace itself can be seen just to the north, its windows partially open if the weather is warm. Nothing in this tranquil place appears to be there by chance. The garden extends to the south and west, but to the east, a platform is built out partially over a small lake.

East.description: A platform begins to the east, leading into a building.

South.description: The garden continues to the south.

West.description: The garden continues to the west, bordered by the palace.

rooms.name: The Emperor's Fountain
rooms.description: Birds of all shapes and descriptions congregate here, at the fountain, to drink the sweet water.  The fountain's bubbling head has been carved to resemble a phoenix, but this doesn't seem to frighten the local wildlife. Small, artfully trimmed and arranged trees are planted in no particular way. Oddly, you see no showy flowers -- just the kinds you might normally see in this climate, like the tiny white blooms of one shy flower thriving in a corner.  The garden's precise, arranged randomness stretches to the north and east.

North.description: The garden continues to the north.

East.description: The garden continues to the east, ending at a pond.

rooms.name: The Emperor's Garden
rooms.description: The main attraction in this part of the garden is the purple elm tree standing vigilantly in the center of the grove.  Gnarled trees fight for sunshine all around it, and ferns and shrubs line the stone walkway you tread so lightly.

North.description: The garden continues to the north. A palace rises behind it.

East.description: You see a calm, almost-round pond to the east.

West.description: The garden continues to the west.

rooms.name: The Chudan
rooms.description: The audience chamber continues in this, the middle step of the three.  The entire room is physically raised higher than the lower step.  One long strip of tatami matting goes the entire length of the audience chamber; two other strips, separated by a thin length of red silk, are on either side of it.  You imagine how awesome a sight it is to see this place filled with nobility, all vying to a seat higher up, toward the emperor's seat to the north.  It must be quite a sight, indeed.  You're glad you're not around to see much of it.

North.description: The soft-feeling tatami matting path continues to the north, but is built on a higher platform than this part of the chamber is.

South.description: The chamber continues to the south. Oddly, it seems as though it is built upon a lower platform than this one.

West.description: You see a very subtle discolored line in the wall here. A black wooden panel reveals a keyhole right in the center of the line.

rooms.name: The Jodan
rooms.description: The narrow tatami strip in the center of the long audience chamber leads here, at last.  You look around in wonder at the high ceiling, at the wood walls that somehow make the chamber three times bigger than it really is, at how everything here seems to point to the end of the room as if it were the climax of the entire island.  Maybe it is.  This part of the chamber is raised still a little more from the middle step.  A dais at the far end of the room is raised still more, and a gold-embroidered cushion set in its center makes it obvious whose seat THIS is.  Vases of exotic flowers are set to either side of the dais.  Behind the dais you see a recessed alcove with an old-looking black and white painting of a mountain.  You can only go south from here.

South.description: When you look south, you're amazed at how large this chamber is!

rooms.name: The Entrance to the Secret Corridor
rooms.description: The door clicks shut behind you.  There is no way out.  If it weren't for your own light sources, there would be no light, either.  The corridor, for you see it's a corridor once your eyes adjust to the darkness, goes on to the north.  Your hands feel along the corridor, but it is standard stone, and unornamented.  No matter how hard your hands scrabble on the hard stone, you can't find any way east.  North is the only visible way out.  You wonder what you'll find...

North.description: The hallway to the north is forbiddingly cold and quiet.

East.description: You can't find any door or opening here! You're trapped!

extras.text: Your hands scrabble to find the way back east, but no matter how hard you look, you can't find a way back.

rooms.name: The Secret Corridor
rooms.description: The corridor runs from north to south.  The cold stone walls are dank, forbidding, and utterly dark.  Your eyes strain to the north -- you can hear something sinister there.  You are beginning to wonder if this was such a good idea, coming here.

North.description: Do you hear that inhuman snarling coming from the north?

South.description: The corridor continues to the south. It's so dark!

rooms.name: The Guarded Doorway
rooms.description: The corridor ends here, at a simple doorway set into the stone wall. Narrow walls press in together, along with the dank scent that seems to accompany the underground world.  There are no light sources here, so it is quite dark.

North.description: The door is forbiddingly large and utterly plain.

South.description: The corridor continues to the south.

rooms.name: The Wizard's Sanctum Sanctorum
rooms.description: The great wizard Yajiro created this sanctuary as a place to get away from the cares of this world, and to contemplate his evil plans upon Odaishyozen. As such, you see many, many books upon his shelves, with titles that make your skin crawl from horror.  Yajiro has been busy, all right.  A grimoire stands open on a stand in one corner, illuminated by a lamp whose cover is made of skin of some kind.  You glance at it, and are horrified to realize that it is a spell for capturing a deity.  A mirror winks in one corner.  Other than going back to the south, there doesn't seem to be any way out of here.

North.description: The image of a beautiful, screaming woman is reflected in this man-sized mirror.

South.description: A very plain door stands to the south.

extras.text: You're quite sure that this is the way through to the woman in the mirror, but none of your efforts open a way through. Perhaps you need a special object... One that the wizard Yajiro thought no one would guess.

She screams out in anguish at being captured -- and it is fairly obvious that she has been tortured, as well, judging by her many injuries. She glows with an otherworldly light. You cannot understand her words, but it's clear that she is both tormented and furious.

rooms.name: Kannon's Cell
rooms.description: When you think of a place fit to imprison a goddess, this is not what comes to mind.  It's dank, musty, and the screams of other prisoners filter in.  The walls are dark, and seem enchanted, because you have the overwhelming impression that they are closing in, closer and closer to you, until you can barely catch your breath for fear of being suffocated.  Nothing else in the room catches your attention besides the cage in the center of the room.  You approach it gingerly, swallowing your fear at the raging goddess trapped in it.

North.description: The Cage of Thorns is in the center of the room. You could enter it by going north, you think.

South.description: You can feel the sheer evil pulsing from the south. A bit of pulsing in the wall seems your only escape from the cage, but to open it, you will need something truly special.

extras.text: The cage has a woman in it. Without getting closer, though, you can tell only that it's a dark, dank place.

rooms.name: The Cage of Thorns
rooms.description: The cage in the middle of the room is cruelly built, with thick iron bars, the bane of all supernatural folk.  The bars are thorned, to prevent their being touched or held onto.  The entire cage glistens with an unnatural sheen-- And you realize that this cage is what a wizard's soul is worth.

South.description: You can exit this dank cage by going south.

rooms.name: The Ocean Bay
rooms.description: The vast ocean to the south is one vast, featureless, azure plain. However, a narrow arm of grey rock begins just to the north, extending like a protecting cloak around a lighter blue channel heading toward an island far away.

North.description: Northwards, the bay opens into a long ocean channel.

South.description: To the south, the ocean begins, vast and deep.

rooms.name: The Channel
rooms.description: A narrow channel of light blue water forms a path through an otherwise featureless ocean.  It is girded on the western side by a spur of grey, craggy rock that leads straight toward an island that's some distance from here.

North.description: The channel continues to the north, the waters growing more turgid by the moment.

South.description: The channel empties into a wide bay to your south.

rooms.name: The Channel
rooms.description: A craggy outcropping of rock, barely wide enough to walk upon, forms a protective arm around a light blue channel of water that extends from north to south, toward a distant island that is at least partially obscured from vast amounts of ocean spray rising from what must be an extraordinarily large whirlpool.

North.description: The channel continues to the north, you think.

South.description: The channel continues to the south.

rooms.name: The Channel
rooms.description: A channel of azure blue water ends here, just before a massive whirlpool to the north.  The flotsam and jetsam of many boats litters the water.  The noise of the whirlpool to the north is deafening, and the spray limits visibility.

North.description: You think you're approaching the end of the channel.

South.description: The channel continues to the south.

rooms.name: The Whirlpool
rooms.description: Rushing, roaring, deafening water forms a massive whirlpool that would terrify even the most hardened sailor.  Swirling waters form a white-capped surf, and nothing at all is visible around or beyond the blinding spray.  It might be possible to swing out of the whirlpool to the north.

North.description: Gasping for breath, you see the end of the channel to the north.

South.description: You see the inlet and bay to your south.

rooms.name: An Inlet
rooms.description: The roar of water to the south deafens, but here, the noise seems almost hollow.  This inlet is fairly calm, and thickly humid with cool waterspray. The water laps gently at a white-pebbled shoreline.  To the north, an emerald green island rises out of the deep azure waters, and a shining gate is visible not too far to the north.

North.description: The white-pebbled shoreline beckons you from the north.

South.description: The roaring whirlpool south of you screams for your blood.
